newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS - French car sales fall 21 percent in March.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - French car sales fall 21 percent in March.

text.p: New car sales in France fell 21 percent in March, the third consecutive monthly drop, from inflated year-earlier levels, the French carmakers association CCFA said on Tuesday.
Sales fell to 151,586 units from 191,942 in March 1996.
For the first three months of the year, car sales in France were down 26.5 percent, it said in a statement. They fell 24.6 percent in February and 33.6 percent in January.
"The (March) results, while an improvement over recent months, show the market suffers from the sales pulled forward by the car rebate incentives," the CCFA said.
Orders surged ahead of the expiry last September of a year-long state rebate scheme as buyers rushed to take advantage of discounts. But sales and orders have slumped since then.

CCFA chairman Yves de Belabre told a news conference he expected sales to improve in coming months, but the market would show a full-year drop of between 10 and 11 percent to around 1.9 million units.
His forecast is in line with those of the French carmakers, Renault SA and PSA Peugeot Citroen.

Belabre said the distorting effects of the rebates were starting to ease. The slow growth of the French car market, which has not recovered the 1989-1992 sales levels of more than two million units, suggests many old vehicles are due for replacement. "That's why we're reasonably optimistic," he said.
Last month's fall also reflected the fact that there were 20 business days, compared with 21 in March 1996. On a comparable basis, the sales drop was 17.1 percent, the CCFA said.
Renault and PSA Peugeot Citroen took 55.4 percent of the market in March and foreign carmakers had 44.6 percent.

Renault's new car sales fell 23.3 percent, giving it a 28 percent market share. Sales of the PSA group, which makes Peugeot and Citroen cars, fell 25.1 percent, leaving it with 27.4 percent of the French car market last month.
Of the foreign car makers, Volvo was the only one to show a gain. Its sales rose 9.6 percent but its market share is only half of one percent.
Mercedes, Volkswagen and the Japanese carmakers showed sales declines of less than five percent.
GM, Ford and Fiat and BMW-Rover showed double-digit sales declines.
